contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''John Nesbitt''' (1925-1998) was a [[Manitoba]] [[agrology|agrologist]]. He worked as a [[university]] professor, and in 1970 challenged [[Israel Asper]] for the leadership of the [[Manitoba Liberal Party]]. Born in [[Shoal Lake, Manitoba|Shoal Lake]], [[Manitoba]], Nesbitt saw service in [[World War II]] and subsequently obtained a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from [[Penn State University]] in 1952. He was head of the department of Dairy Science at the [[University of Manitoba]] from 1953 to 1966, and was a respected public speaker. He was also a member of Manitoba's Milk Control Board from 1959 to 1970. Despite having the support of House Leader [[Gordon Johnston (Canadian politician)|Gordon Johnston]], Nesbitt received only 329 votes at the provincial Liberal convention of 1970, as against 720 for Asper. Nesbitt returned to the [[University of Manitoba]] in 1977, serving as Associate Director (and later Director) of the School of Agriculture. In 1984, he helped to found [[Keystone Agricultural Producers Inc.]] He never actually ran for office at the provincial or federal level. {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Nesbitt, John | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1925 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1988 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nesbitt, John}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians in Manitoba]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University alumni]] [[Category:University of Manitoba faculty]] [[Category:Dairy educators]]
